channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: A job with real flexibility. 100% remote Perl position
item.description: As one of the most popular open-source ticketing systems on the planet, this team knows what it takes to attract organizations of all sizes. Looking for a Perl developer who has Mason, Moose, Mojolicious and experience with ticketing systems.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: This company offers the perfect blend of creativity and process. They’ve been around long enough to know what they’re doing, but they thrive on innovation and aren’t stuck doing things the same way just because that’s how it was done before. You’ll have the opportunity to try new things, particularly on Hacker Days, where programmers have the chance to work on features of their choice.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK/EU Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: We know that a lack of commercial experience doesn’t always reflect skill level, know-how, or programming brilliance. You know your stuff. You’re keen to grow and learn. You know that if someone would only just give you a chance, and let you in the door, you could really shine!

item.title: Make a Difference AND a Paycheque. 100% remote (within the UK) Mid-level Perl developer role
item.description: If you’ve got experience with Python, so much the better, but Perl is a must-have for this role. You’ll be a whiz with databases like PostgreSQL and MySQL, and you’ll write tidy, easily-maintained HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Technical skills are important, but they aren’t the whole picture. If you’re eager to learn and have a great attitude, this client embraces on the job learning.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Perl Tk: The label, button, and entry widgets
Week 138 Task 1 Workdays
item.description: Nice to see Steven found time to blog about his solution. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 138
item.description: Simon is one of the few PWC members who always promotes the weekly challenge on dev.to. Thank you for supporting us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Split Work
item.description: I liked how Roger picked Raku to talk about the Workdays task. Great example of code reuse. As always, thank you for your support and encouragement.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138
item.description: Luis' blog's main attraction for me is the Perl one liners. It is not always easy to read but I like to challenge myself at times. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: split working days
item.description: Luca once again shares Raku and bonus solutions in PostgreSQL. Luca keeps things simple and I find it easy to follow. Thanks for sharing your knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Workdays and Split Number
item.description: Very compact solutions in Perl and Raku as always by Laurent. He always gets to the point without wasting time. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #138
item.description: James' observation about the task is unique. He has the ability to get to the bottom of each task and shares the knowledge. You really don't want to miss out. Thank you for sharing your experience with us.

item.title: PWC138 - Split Number
item.description: A very interesting approach to the 'Split Number' task. I had to read the text twice to understand the flow. I loved the logic - something to keep in mind.

item.title: PWC138 - Workdays
item.description: Flavio using a 'subset' of Raku is nice and clean. Nice mathematical hack to get the end result. You are a great storyteller too. Thanks for entertaining us every week.

item.title: I Thank You For The Days: The Weekly Challenge #138
item.description: What I like about Dave's blog is that he not only discusses the task but also gives bonus material related to the task. Incredible. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #138 Task 1 and Some Previous Tasks on Calendar Date
item.description: Cheok-Yin is back with a cool blog post, collections of more than just one week. I loved the narrations. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Workdays are Numbered with Raku (and Perl)
item.description: Arne is one of the PWC members who I follow when it comes to Raku programming. His style of blogging is apt for any new learner. Thank you for everything.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Split Number
item.description: Abigail's use of mathematical formulae is fascinating. And then getting that translated into a subroutine is amazing. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 138: Workdays
item.description: Abigail's blog post has a nice bonus, I noticed, where you can live demo the solution. Really cool. Thanks for the support and encouragement.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Paulo Custodio
item.description: Get to know about Paulo Custodio.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 138
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Workdays" and "Split Number" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 139
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "JortSort" and "Long Primes". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: I finally start to translate Japanese Perl Zemi to English
item.description: Perl Zemi is a Japanese Perl Tutorial site which is well-known and read in Japan.

item.title: I made a calculator
item.description: Build a calculator using wxGlade.

item.title: DBD::Oracle
item.description: Installing DBD::Oracle in Perl

item.title: A dream resyntaxed
item.description: Damian's take on the subject Curtis wrote about in his latest blog post.

item.title: Language Design Consistency
item.description: As we know, Curtis and his team are working on Corinna and we keep getting regular updates. The latest blog post is talking about design consistency.

item.title: My Favorite (?) Warnings - Ex-Warnings
item.description: Please check out Tom's blog post on another favourite.

item.title: Taming the Moose: Classing up Perl attributes
item.description: Find out ways to tame a Moose, thanks to Mark.

item.title: Perl OpenAPI with Mojolicious
item.description: Find out the power of OpenAPI.

item.title: Perl LDAP
item.description: Cool mix of LDAP and Perl.

item.title: Processing dates and times with Perl
item.description: I sometimes miss Dave's blog posts but this time I have made sure you all get the benefit of his writing. It is great post talking about different CPAN modules for dealing with dates.

item.title: open invitation to participate in Perl-OpenMP on Github
item.description: Please do join Perl-OpenMP.

item.title: The ephemeral miniconf
item.description: The Ephemeral Miniconf is planned for Thursday 18 November 2021.

item.title: #538 - Are you Perl blogger?
item.description:
Hi there

Going back to the editorial of last week's edition of Perl Weekly, it is still there in my head raising many questions. It is a universal fact that Perl is no longer the favourite language among the youths in college these days. I remember when I was first introduced to Perl in 1999, it was the most popular language. Being a Perl fan, I feel it is my responsibility to bring Perl back to the discussion table. One way to do that is to talk about Perl-based projects and share them with the users of other languages. I have noticed that not as many people blog about Perl as they used to in the past. Talking about blogs, I would like to thank The Weekly Challenge team for spreading the power of Perl. For the record, in the last 138 weeks, the team have created and shared over 2000 blog posts. I used to blog regularly in the past but nowadays I hardly find time. Having said that, I still wrte a monthly report blog post where I talk about Perl and my other projects. I find making a live video is less time consuming than writing a blog post. I made some and then I stopped that as well, sorry. You can take a look my YouTube Channel if you fancy. I came across series of videos by Gabor Szabo teaching Perl. It is great source for someone new to Perl and explore with live action.

I remember, Dave Cross, wrote a blog post talking about something that not many people would speak about. I personally agree with him fully and believe knowing more than one programming languages helps you as a programmer. I can tell from my own experience, I picked up Raku last year while participating the weekly challenge. Whatever little I know about Raku to date, I can tell it has helped me a lot. I use that knowledge to write better Perl programs. Recently, I started writing Python as well - just the basics for now. So the question is, does knowing Raku or Python make me any less of a Perl programmer? I am still a Perl programmer and all of my thought processes still follow Perl's rules. Perl is my first love and will remain so for the rest of my life. Even today, after more than 22 years, I find features that I never knew existed before, especially in the field of regex. I would like to give credit to Abigail for sharing the magic of regex in Perl as part of his weekly contributions.

While talking about blogs, how can I miss those who are doing great service on a regular basis? I would like to thank Flavio Poletti for blogging every day for months now. Also there is another name, Mark Gardner, who writes a weekly blog post. Similarly we have weekly stats by Miguel Prz.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
